description: Possibly suggested by fluff and flop. US; as verb from 1924, noun from 1953.

entries.meaning: (informal) An error; a mistake in the performance of an action.
examples: I made a talk on television, a talk in which I made a flub—one of the few that I make, not because I′m so good on television but because I′ve been doing it a long time. I made a flub in which I said I was running for governor of the United States.

verbs.description: flub (third-person singular simple present flubs, present participle flubbing, simple past and past participle flubbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To goof, fumble, or err in the performance of an action.
examples: ‘Stage fright? So? What are you babbling ′bout? You′re mad as a snake!’
‘Ever since I was a kid. I was in the Christmas Pageant one year and flubbed my line.’
‘I told you I flubbed it!’ he mouthed these words hysterically.
